linkTarget.anchoringText: Two sand-rich, thick reservoir intervals of Upper Boscan and Lower Boscan are stratigraphically separated by the Boscan Shale (Figure 1a). These reservoirs are composed of tidal channels and bars deposited in a tidally-influenced fluvial-deltaic environment during the Eocene as part of the Misoa Formation. The reservoir has a south-southwest dip of 2 deg, resulting in the depth varying between ~4,000 ft. in the north to ~9,600 ft. in the south (Figure 1b). This results in variations in pressure, temperature and fluid properties (e.g. oil viscosity) across the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: (a) Type log (Shannon et al., 2014. Two reservoir intervals of Upper Boscan (UB) and Lower Boscan (LB) are stratigraphically separated by the Boscan Shale (BS). An unconformity (shown by red curve line) caps the UB reservoir. Significant break in pressure was found in the UB and LB reservoirs (not shown here) and, therefore, BS is considered a transmissibility barrier between the two reservoirs. (b) Structural map (Mendez et al., 2014). The reservoir dips to the southwest, resulting in the depth varying between ~4000 ft. in the north to ~9600 ft. in the south. The reservoirs are bounded by the Boscan fault in east and limited by an aquifer in south.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Type log (Shannon et al., 2014. Two reservoir intervals of Upper Boscan (UB) and Lower Boscan (LB) are stratigraphically separated by the Boscan Shale (BS). An unconformity (shown by red curve line) caps the UB reservoir. Significant break in pressure was found in the UB and LB reservoirs (not shown here) and, therefore, BS is considered a transmissibility barrier between the two reservoirs. (b) Structural map (Mendez et al., 2014 ). The reservoir dips to the southwest, resulting in the depth varying between ~4000 ft. in the north to ~9600 ft. in the south. The reservoirs are bounded by the Boscan fault in east and limited by an aquifer in south.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Type log (Shannon et al., 2014. Two reservoir intervals of Upper Boscan (UB) and Lower Boscan (LB) are stratigraphically separated by the Boscan Shale (BS)
Structural map (Mendez et al., 2014 ). The reservoir dips to the southwest, resulting in the depth varying between ~4000 ft

linkTarget.bib:
Mendez et al., 2014
A Mendez ., B Chacin ., S Balram ., and B Smith ., 2014.Successful Application of Water Injection to Increase Oil Recovery in Boscan Field. SPE-169412-MS. https://doi.org/10.2118/169412-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: These reservoirs are composed of tidal channels and bars deposited in a tidally-influenced fluvial-deltaic environment during the Eocene as part of the Misoa Formation. The reservoir has a south-southwest dip of 2 deg, resulting in the depth varying between ~4,000 ft. in the north to ~9,600 ft. in the south (Figure 1b). This results in variations in pressure, temperature and fluid properties (e.g. oil viscosity) across the field. The average porosity and permeability of the field are 23% and 500 md, respectively. The cross-plot of porosity and permeability are shown in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: core-based permeability vs. PHIT (Coleen et al. 2014).

formatted-caption.caption-text: core-based permeability vs. PHIT (Coleen et al. 2014).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The large depth variation in the field (4,000 – 9,600 ft.) causes significant change in reservoir temperature and pressure, as shown in Figure 3. Unlike light oil, heavy-oil viscosity is a strong function of temperature (Figure 4a). Additionally, variation in the reservoir pressure is associated with differences in the amount of dissolved gas and the degree of undersaturation and therefore, oil viscosity is also a function of reservoir pressure (Figure 4b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir temperature variation in the UB reservoir. Due to large reservoir depth variation, significant temperature (150-190 °F) changes are observed across the reservoir. Please note that the reservoir temperature significantly affects heavy-oil viscosity as illustrated in Figure 4a below.Temperature (degF) Pressure (psia)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir temperature variation in the UB reservoir. Due to large reservoir depth variation, significant temperature (150-190 °F) changes are observed across the reservoir. Please note that the reservoir temperature significantly affects heavy-oil viscosity as illustrated in Figure 4a below.Temperature (degF) Pressure (psia)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The large depth variation in the field (4,000 – 9,600 ft.) causes significant change in reservoir temperature and pressure, as shown in Figure 3. Unlike light oil, heavy-oil viscosity is a strong function of temperature (Figure 4a). Additionally, variation in the reservoir pressure is associated with differences in the amount of dissolved gas and the degree of undersaturation and therefore, oil viscosity is also a function of reservoir pressure (Figure 4b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: (a) Dead oil-viscosity with temperature (b) Live oil-viscosity variation with pressure for three temperature conditions; the plot doesn’t illustrate undersaturated part of the curve.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Dead oil-viscosity with temperature (b) Live oil-viscosity variation with pressure for three temperature conditions; the plot doesn’t illustrate undersaturated part of the curve.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Live oil-viscosity variation with pressure for three temperature conditions

linkTarget.anchoringText: Drilling started in 1947 with 214 ac/well (1,000 m spacing) using 7-spot hexagonal patterns. In 1956, an infill drilling program was implemented with 71 ac/well (577 m spacing). Although, government regulation required a minimum 600 m spacing for Eocene reservoirs, 577 m was accepted as it was close to the regulation while achieving equidistance between adjacent wells inside the original 1,000 m well spacing (Figure 5a). After 1996, the reservoir was developed only at 577 m spacing with some exceptions due to surface limitations, multi-pad drilling, and deviated wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: (a) The Boscan field was initially developed (1947-1960) on 1000 m spacing, but subsequently (since 1960) been developed on 577m spacing (Plaza et al., 2014). (b) Pseudo 1-3-1 configuration is being used in WIPM for Area B and Phase 1 development. This configuration uses an additional row of producers between conventional inverted 7-spot patterns.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) The Boscan field was initially developed (1947-1960) on 1000 m spacing, but subsequently (since 1960) been developed on 577m spacing (Plaza et al., 2014 ). (b) Pseudo 1-3-1 configuration is being used in WIPM for Area B and Phase 1 development. This configuration uses an additional row of producers between conventional inverted 7-spot patterns.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The Boscan field was initially developed (1947-1960) on 1000 m spacing, but subsequently (since 1960) been developed on 577m spacing (Plaza et al., 2014)
Pseudo 1-3-1 configuration is being used in WIPM for Area B and Phase 1 development

linkTarget.bib:
Plaza et al., 2014
R Plaza ., M Pernalete ., B Smith . et al. 2014. A Novel Approach to Analyzing and Managing Well Spacing and Density in Boscan Field, Western Venezuela. SPE-169466-MS. https://doi.org/10.2118/169466-MS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Water injection in the Boscan field was initiated between 1957 and 1963 as water disposal with no fixed configuration (Mendez, et al., 2014). In 1997, four inverted 7-spot patterns were developed as a Water Injection and Pressure Maintenance (WIPM) pilot in the central portion of the field, named Area A (Figure 6). Based on the data analysis of water disposal area, Area A performance and reservoir modeling, the WIPM projects were expanded into Area B (8 patterns in 2004) and Phase 1 (8 patterns in 2007 & 2011). The expansion projects used vertical wells in a pseudo 1-3-1 inverted 7-spot pattern configuration as shown in Figure 5b.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: More than 1000 wells have been drilled in Boscán in ~70 years of field development. Water Injection and Pressure Maintenance (WIPM) is in the central portion of the field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: More than 1000 wells have been drilled in Boscán in ~70 years of field development. Water Injection and Pressure Maintenance (WIPM) is in the central portion of the field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The primary production data analysis quantified the impact of the reservoir depth (oil viscosity and pressure) on initial production (IP) rate, a key well performance indicator. Only early wells, those drilled before the start of infill drilling or waterflooding, were considered for this analysis. The mid-perforation depth of each well was considered its target reservoir depth. Figure 7 displays well IP vs depth, showing a clear trend with higher IPs in deeper reservoirs. An average of initial production rates in deeper areas of the reservoir is more than double that of the shallower area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: An average of initial production rates of deeper area of the reservoir is more than double that of shallower area. Only the early wells (before start of infill/water-injection) were considered for this analysis (Kumar et al., 2015).

formatted-caption.caption-text: An average of initial production rates of deeper area of the reservoir is more than double that of shallower area. Only the early wells (before start of infill/water-injection) were considered for this analysis (Kumar et al., 2015 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Kumar et al., 2015
R. Kumar , C. Lolley , and K. Radecker
2015. Dynamic Model Calibration of North Boscan Leads to Improved Understanding of a Heavy-oil Reservoir Behavior. Presented at World Heavy Oil Congress at Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, 25-26 March . WHOC15-179.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Production and injection data from 20 patterns in Area A, Area B, and Phase 1 (~ 150 producers) provided a significant data set to assess the impact of waterflooding (Figure 8). Reservoir pressure maps were also created, combining data from multiple sources to provide additional insights into the field behavior. Pressure measurements across the field included open-hole logging (MDT/XPT), build-up/fall- off tests, and static fluid-level in shut-in wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Water Injection and Pressure Maintenance (WIPM) region constitutes 3 areas: Area A, Area B and Phase 1; pattern names for each of these areas were given for data analysis: four Area A patterns are identified as A-I through A-IV; eight Area B patterns are identified as B-I through B-VIII; eight Phase 1 patterns are identified as Ph 1 -I through Ph1 -VIII.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Injection and Pressure Maintenance (WIPM) region constitutes 3 areas: Area A, Area B and Phase 1; pattern names for each of these areas were given for data analysis: four Area A patterns are identified as A-I through A-IV; eight Area B patterns are identified as B-I through B-VIII; eight Phase 1 patterns are identified as Ph 1 -I through Ph1 -VIII.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analysis of production response shows additional recovery of ~3% after the start of waterflood. Figure 9a and Figure 9b show oil recovery versus hydrocarbon pore volume injected (HCPVI) for Area A and individual patterns of Phase 1. After 25+ years of water injection in Area A and 10 years in Phase 1, cumulative water injection is still less than 10% of the hydrocarbon pore volume. The low HCPVI is attributed to the large spacing (577 m) and limited injectivity. Low HCPVI till date also highlight significant recovery potential remaining in the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (a) Per project additional recovery after start of water-injection in Area A plotted against HCPVI.(b) Per pattern additional recovery after the start of water-injection in Phase 1 plotted against HCPVI.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Per project additional recovery after start of water-injection in Area A plotted against HCPVI.(b) Per pattern additional recovery after the start of water-injection in Phase 1 plotted against HCPVI.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Per project additional recovery after start of water-injection in Area A plotted against HCPVI
Per pattern additional recovery after the start of water-injection in Phase 1 plotted against HCPVI

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 show the average oil production rate and water cut for four patterns, two in Area A and two in Phase 1, respectively. The plots separate the response of wells located in the first-row and in the second-row from the injector. The key observation is that the second-row producers exhibit similar oil response (peak rates and decline) as the first-row producers after the start of water injection, but significantly lower water cut. It is important to note that due to the adverse mobility, recovery efficiencies are poor, and high water cut is observed even at small HCPVI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Oil production rate per well and water cut for two Area A patterns (a) II, (b) III (pattern names are identified in Figure 7). Surprisingly, Area A-II second row produces more oil (still at lower water cut) than first row, perhaps caused by local variations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production rate per well and water cut for two Area A patterns (a) II, (b) III (pattern names are identified in Figure 7). Surprisingly, Area A-II second row produces more oil (still at lower water cut) than first row, perhaps caused by local variations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 show the average oil production rate and water cut for four patterns, two in Area A and two in Phase 1, respectively. The plots separate the response of wells located in the first-row and in the second-row from the injector. The key observation is that the second-row producers exhibit similar oil response (peak rates and decline) as the first-row producers after the start of water injection, but significantly lower water cut. It is important to note that due to the adverse mobility, recovery efficiencies are poor, and high water cut is observed even at small HCPVI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Oil production rate per well and water cut for two Phase 1 patterns (a) II, (b) VIII. These two patterns of Phase 1 are not impacted by water encroachment from aquifer in the south.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production rate per well and water cut for two Phase 1 patterns (a) II, (b) VIII. These two patterns of Phase 1 are not impacted by water encroachment from aquifer in the south.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analysis of field data shows pressure response extending up to the second row producers. This is illustrated in Figure 12 with snapshots of reservoir pressure in Area A in 1996 (before injection), 1999, 2004, and 2007. Pressure after the impact of water injection ranges between 1,850 – 3,000 psi, while nonimpacted area has been depleted to less than 1,300 psi. Localized pressure behavior is observed due to high oil viscosity, and pressure impact beyond two rows of producers is minimal.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Pressure maps at different time created from field data near Area A. Primary production resulted into significant depletion in the field. Pressure near Area A is lower than the bubblepoint pressure before water injection. Localized pressure transients (depletion and buildup) are observed due to high oil viscosity.1996,1999,2004,2007.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure maps at different time created from field data near Area A. Primary production resulted into significant depletion in the field. Pressure near Area A is lower than the bubblepoint pressure before water injection. Localized pressure transients (depletion and buildup) are observed due to high oil viscosity.1996,1999,2004,2007.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The proposed configuration essentially converts the 1-3-1 configuration to 1-5-1, with 5 rows of producers between two adjacent rows of injectors, as shown in Figure 13.Figure 13 also illustrates a symmetry element pattern (shown by dotted red line) that is used for evaluation of this proposed configuration vis- a-vis conventional inverted 7-spot infill pattern for their production performance. Table 1 compares the number of additional wells for alternative infill configurations in a symmetry element pattern.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Proposed Infill Configuration uses existing injector and additional producers between first and second row of existing producers. A symmetry element pattern is also shown by dotted red line; symmetry element pattern is used for evaluation of this proposed configuration vis-a-vis conventional inverted 7-spot infill pattern.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proposed Infill Configuration uses existing injector and additional producers between first and second row of existing producers. A symmetry element pattern is also shown by dotted red line; symmetry element pattern is used for evaluation of this proposed configuration vis-a-vis conventional inverted 7-spot infill pattern.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A representative symmetry-element sector from the calibrated model (discussed in a subsequent section “Full-field Model Calibration”) was used to evaluate and compare the performance of alternative infill configurations. We use the symmetry element to show the pattern configurations for the current WF configuration (Figure 14a) and two alternative infill configurations: the proposed infills (Figure 14b) and conventional inverted 7-spot (Figure 14c).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: A representative symmetry element sector was used to evaluate potential of alternative infill configurations with (a) base case of WF, (b) Proposed infill configuration using existing injectors and additional infill producers between first and second row of existing producers, (c) Conventional inverted 7-spot infill configuration.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A representative symmetry element sector was used to evaluate potential of alternative infill configurations with (a) base case of WF, (b) Proposed infill configuration using existing injectors and additional infill producers between first and second row of existing producers, (c) Conventional inverted 7-spot infill configuration.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proposed infill configuration using existing injectors and additional infill producers between first and second row of existing producers

linkTarget.anchoringText: The calculation using the representative dynamic model shows that the novel configuration can achieve similar recoveries as the conventional smaller spacing alternatives, but with fewer number of wells and smaller amount of water injected into the reservoir (Figure 15a and Figure 15b). Water cut of the infill producers (between first and second row producers) are smaller than the first-row producers, and therefore pattern level water cut is reduced. Conversely, the poor displacement and sweep efficiencies results into a long tail of production at high water cut (Figure 15c) for conventional infill configuration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Recovery. Injection rates in all the injectors were kept at the same level (assuming limited injectivity in the existing area).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery. Injection rates in all the injectors were kept at the same level (assuming limited injectivity in the existing area).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The infills for the water injection area (Area A, Area B, and Phase 1) were designed using the 1-5-1 configuration (in particular, between Area B and Phase 1) with well spacing of 290 m between producers, as described earlier in the “Infill Configuration Selection” section. For the areas where 1-5-1 could not be implemented (e.g., Area A, south of Phase 1, and the boundary patterns), infills were designed between the first and the second row of producers at 290 m spacing. The Infill-project for Area A, Area B and Phase 1 includes 43, 68 and 76 new producers respectively (Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Infill configuration evaluated for three different areas (a) Area A, (b) Area B and (c) Phase 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Infill configuration evaluated for three different areas (a) Area A, (b) Area B and (c) Phase 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: The models were matched to the regions (or, patterns) for oil and water production and pressure and not on a well-by-well basis. Oil and water production rates from the history matched models (P10, P50 and P90) against the field data are shown in the Figure 17. These set of calibrated models were subsequently used to evaluate infill potential in the WIPM area of the reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: The three calibrated geological models achieve a very good match between observed water production data and simulation results in the WIPM area wells. The simulator control during the history-match (HM) period was set to liquid production rate on well- level and the calibration was done on oil and water production rates.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The three calibrated geological models achieve a very good match between observed water production data and simulation results in the WIPM area wells. The simulator control during the history-match (HM) period was set to liquid production rate on well- level and the calibration was done on oil and water production rates.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Phase 1 infill forecast shows incremental oil recovery of 5.8% over base waterflood case after 30% of hydrocarbon pore volume injected into the reservoir (results for P50 case as shown in Figure 18). The final incremental recovery obtained in the full-field model is similar to that achieved using the representative symmetry element model used for selecting the infill configuration. The main difference in results comes in the rate production profile, as the full-field model incorporated more detailed study (drilling schedule, interference with existing wells, regional geologic characteristics, etc.).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Forecasted Recovery factor with and without infill (waterflood) from Phase 1 for P-50 case.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Forecasted Recovery factor with and without infill (waterflood) from Phase 1 for P-50 case.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In absence of direct analog (configuration and spacing), the performance of proposed infills were compared against the existing producers in the specific areas (Area A, Area B, and Phase 1) under consideration. Figure 19 shows the cumulative distribution function of peak oil production rates of existing wells (577 m spacing) and the corresponding P10, P50, and P90 response. Figure 20 compares the forecasted P10-P50-P90 range of oil production rates from infills with those of the existing wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the peak oil rates of existing wells in Phase 1 and corresponding P10, P50, and P90 values.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the peak oil rates of existing wells in Phase 1 and corresponding P10, P50, and P90 values.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In absence of direct analog (configuration and spacing), the performance of proposed infills were compared against the existing producers in the specific areas (Area A, Area B, and Phase 1) under consideration. Figure 19 shows the cumulative distribution function of peak oil production rates of existing wells (577 m spacing) and the corresponding P10, P50, and P90 response. Figure 20 compares the forecasted P10-P50-P90 range of oil production rates from infills with those of the existing wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of forecasted infill peak rates range compared to the existing producers (see Figure 19). Peak oil rates from infill wells (at spacing of 290 m) are lower than those of the existing wells (at 577 m spacing).
